newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Brash says rapid rise in NZ dlr would harm exports.
newsitem.headline: Brash says rapid rise in NZ dlr would harm exports.

text.p: Reserve Bank Governor Don Brash said on Monday the continued rapid rise in the New Zealand dollar would weaken export growth.
"While our current projections see an increase in export growth over the next few years there are risks.
"In particular, continued rapid strengthening in the exchange rate would considerably weaken export growth," Brash said in a speech to Federated Farmers in Invercargill.
"In view of this risk, it is worth considering whether we have policy measures available that might help reduce the scale of the problem and reduce the risk," Brash said.
Brash said that while many would advocate temporary relaxation of monetary policy it would mean higher short term inflation.
"Tolerating more inflation might result in a lower exchange rate but of course, as all our history proves, that provides only very temporary relief for exporters."
"It is not too long before the higher domestic inflation catches with the temporary benefits conferred by the lower exchange rate," he said.
"In current circumstances, where the domestic economy is already pushing close to its capacity limits, that loss of the temporary benefit arising from a lower exchange rate might happen very quickly.

"And perhaps more importantly over the longer haul allowing a temporary relaxation of the inflation target now would only increase pressure to do the same thing again in the future, something that would get built into inflation expection to the
"Fiddling with medium-term policy in response to temporary problems is almost always unwise."
Brash talked of an ideal scenario where inflation pressures weakened and interest rates, assisted by a supportive fiscal stance, came back more into line with world interest rates.
Brash said a return to price stability associated with a "considerable and unhealthy crunch" to the export sector would be a bad scenario.

"To be sure, the exchange rate would eventually drop sharply -- perhaps in response to a sharp rise in the current account deficit -- but by then serious damage might have been done and the suddeness of the adjustment would itself create further damage," he said.
